questions.question: Question 1: What is the most common site of fistulization in GIT?
questions.explanation:
The esophagus is the most common site of fistulization in the gastrointestinal tract (GIT). A tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF) is an abnormal fistula communication between the esophagus 
and trachea. The fistula is usually present near the tracheal bifurcation, with or without 
esophageal atresia. A blind proximal pouch with a distal tracheooesophageal fistula is the most 
common type of tracheoesophageal fistula (Type C). 10% of the patients have associated VACTERL anomalies (vertebral, anorectal, cardiac, tracheal, 
esophageal, renal, and limb).

questions.question: Question 2: What is the most frequent site of ectopic gastric mucosa?
questions.explanation:
986 
Sold by @itachibot The most frequent site of the ectopic gastric mucosa is the upper third of the esophagus, where it 
is referred to as an inlet patch. It is congenital and mostly asymptomatic. Occasionally, it can release acid, which can result in 
dysphagia, esophagitis, Barrett esophagus, or, rarely, adenocarcinoma.

questions.question:
Question 3: A 57-year-old man came with complaints of difficulty in swallowing and a persistent feeling of 
something stuck in his throat. He also reports bad breath and regurgitation of food particles. 
Barium swallow revealed the following. This condition occurs due to a defect in which of the 
following? 977 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and barium swallow image are diagnostic of Zenker’s diverticulum. It 
occurs due to a defect in the Killian's triangle (Killian's dehiscence). Killian's triangle is an anatomical triangular area bordered superiorly by the firm oblique fibers of 
the thyropharyngeus muscle and inferiorly by the horizontal fibers of the cricopharyngeus muscle. 
It is located immediately above the upper esophageal sphincter. Although the Killian-Jamieson diverticulum is an anterolateral defect, it is rarely symptomatic.

questions.question: Question 4: All of the following may be seen in patients with Plummer-Vinson syndrome except:
questions.explanation:
Paterson–Brown–Kelly or Plummer–Vinson syndrome is associated with non-progressive 
dysphagia, especially with incompletely chewed food. This syndrome is common in women aged >40 years. The other components of this syndrome 
are: • Post-cricoid webs in the upper esophagus • Iron-deficiency anemia • Glossitis • Cheilosis Esophageal webs are idiopathic, semi-circumferential lesions composed of fibrovascular 
connective tissue and overlying epithelium. They are usually limited to the proximal 
esophagus and may cause obstruction. They are associated with: • Plummer–Vinson syndrome • Gastroesophageal reflux disease • Chronic graft-versus-host disease • Blistering skin diseases The images below show endoscopic and barium swallow appearances of esophageal webs. 987 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 6: A 52-year-old woman is being evaluated for dysphagia and chest pain. She traveled to Brazil 
on a business trip 5 months ago. Barium swallow reveals the following finding. Which of the 
following could have caused this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and barium swallow showing the bird-beak appearance are suggestive 
of achalasia cardia. With respect to this patient's travel history, Chagas' disease due to infection 
with Trypanosoma cruzi must be suspected. The infection destroys the myenteric plexus which results in failure of peristalsis and esophageal 
dilatation. Duodenal, colonic, and ureteric myenteric plexuses can also be affected by Chagas' 
disease.

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following statements is true about the pathology of achalasia cardia?

options.c: Decreased release of NO and VIP in the distal part of esophagus
options.d: Decreased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter

questions.explanation:
Achalasia cardia is characterized by decreased release of NO(nitric oxide) and VIP(vasoactive 
intestinal polypeptide) in the distal part of esophagus. Normally, NO and VIP are secreted by the inhibitory neurons of the Auerbach's plexus in the 
distal esophagus. This leads to relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES). In achalasia 
cardia, these inhibitory neurons degenerate leading to decreased release of NO and VIP. This 
causes increased LES tone. The triad of achalasia cardia is as follows: • Incomplete relaxation of LES • Increased tone of LES • Absent peristalsis (aperistalisis)

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following is incorrect about eosinophilic esophagitis?

options.a: Majority of patients have associated atopic conditions
options.b: Feline esophagus is an endoscopic finding
options.c: Treatment of choice is systemic steroids
options.d: May be associated with food products like cow’s milk and soy products

questions.explanation:
Treatment of choice are proton pump inhibitors, which when started as primary therapy is 
effective in 30 - 50 % of affected individuals. Additionally, elimination of allergenic proteins from diet as it is is associated with atopy and 
exposure to food allergens like cow’s milk and soy products. Swallowed topical steroids are used as well. Immunocompromised patients are treated with acyclovir, famciclovir or valacyclovir. Factors

questions.question:
Question 10: A 47-year-old woman comes to you with progressive heartburn and difficulty in swallowing. 
She also describes episodes of painful blanching and bluish discoloration of her fingers and 
toes on exposure to cold. The following findings are noted on examination. Antibodies to 
which of the following are most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.explanation:
The symptoms of the patient in the above case scenario and the image showing calcinosis are the 
characteristic findings of the CREST syndrome or limited scleroderma. Patients with this 
condition characteristically have antibodies directed against centromeric proteins 
(anti-centromere antibodies). CREST syndrome is characterized by the following: • Calcinosis • Raynaud phenomenon • Esophageal dysmotility • Sclerodactyly • Telangiectasia In the esophagus, progressive atrophy and fibrous replacement of the muscularis propria leads to 
hypomotility and dysphagia. The lower 2/3 of the esophagus develops a 
rubber-hose–like inflexibility. The associated dysfunction of the lower esophageal sphincter gives 
rise to gastroesophageal reflux, Barrett metaplasia, and stricture.

questions.question:
Question 11: A 50-year-old man presented with blood in his vomitus. He gives a history of binge drinking 
followed by multiple episodes of vomiting the prior night. He is hemodynamically stable. 981 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following is incorrect about this condition?

options.a: It is due to longitudinal mucosal tears
options.b: The gastroesophageal musculature fails to relax
options.c: The tears cross the gastroesophageal junction

questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of a Mallory–Weiss tear. They require only conservative 
management and healing tends to be rapid and complete. They are longitudinal mucosal tears that may cross the gastroesophageal junction (GEJ). 
Forceful retching or vomiting along with failure of reflex relaxation of the gastroesophageal 
musculature results in tears involving the mucosa and submucosa. It usually occurs secondary to 
conditions like acute alcohol intoxication or hyperemesis gravidarum. Boerhaave syndrome is a much more serious disorder characterized by transmural rupture of the 
distal esophagus. This results in acute mediastinitis with severe chest pain, tachypnea, and shock. 
Such patients generally require urgent surgical intervention. 991 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 12: What is the most frequent cause of esophagitis?
questions.explanation:
The most frequent cause of esophagitis is reflux of gastric acid into the lower esophagus. The most common cause of gastroesophageal reflux is transient lower esophageal sphincter 
relaxation. Reflux esophagitis leads to chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). This can 
cause Barrett's esophagus and eventually can cause adenocarcinoma.

questions.question: Question 13: Which organism can cause esophageal infections in healthy individuals?
questions.explanation:
Esophagitis in healthy individuals can be caused by the Herpes simplex virus. However, it is 
relatively uncommon. In immunosuppressed individuals, infections can be caused by: • Herpes simplex virus • Cytomegalovirus • Candida

questions.question: Question 14: Punched-out ulcers in the esophagus are caused by:
questions.explanation:
Infection with Herpes simplex virus (HSV) typically results in punched-out ulcers in the 
esophagus. HSV esophagitis commonly occurs in immunocompromised patients. For diagnosis, the biopsy 
sample should be taken from the edge of the ulcer. The following microscopic findings are noted: • Ballooning degeneration • Ground-glass changes in nuclei • Cowdry type A intranuclear inclusion bodies 992 
Sold by @itachibot Note: CMV esophagitis causes shallow ulcerations. The biopsy is taken from the base of the ulcer 
and shows characteristic nuclear and cytoplasmic inclusions bodies.

questions.question:
Question 15: 982 
Sold by @itachibot A 2•-year-old patient with haematemesis is found to have the following finding on upper GI 
endoscopy. He has traveled to Zambia several times over the past 3 years. What could be the 
likely cause of this condition?
questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario and image showing bleeding esophageal varices are suggestive of hepatic 
schistosomiasis. It is the second most common cause of varices worldwide. Liver cirrhosis, mostly in association with alcoholic liver disease, is the most common cause of 
varices.

questions.question: Question 16: All are true about Barrett oesophagus except:

options.b: Seen in 10% of individuals with symptomatic GERD
options.c: Increases risk of squamous cell carcinoma

questions.explanation:
Barrett's esophagus increases the risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma, not squamous cell 
carcinoma. Barrett's esophagus is a complication of GERD and it is estimated to occur in as many as 10% of 
individuals with symptomatic GERD. Microscopically, it is seen as the replacement of the 
squamous esophageal epithelium with goblet cells (intestinal metaplasia). The following images show endoscopic and microscopic images of Barrett's esophagus: 993 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 18: Which of the following statements is false?

options.a: The most common site of extranodal lymphoma in GIT is the esophagus
options.b: The most common benign tumour of esophagus is leimyoma
options.c: The most common esophageal cancer overall is squamous cell carcinoma
options.d: The most common esophageal cancer in Western countries is adenocarcinoma

questions.explanation: The most common site of extranodal lymphoma in GIT is the stomach, not the esophagus.

questions.question: Question 19: Which of the following is not a predisposing factor for esophageal cancer?
questions.explanation:
Mediastinal fibrosis does not predispose to esophageal carcinoma. Risk factors for esophageal 
carcinoma include the following: • Alcohol and tobacco use • Poverty • Caustic alkali burns • Diverticula • Achalasia • Tylosis • Plummer–Vinson syndrome • Frequent consumption of very hot beverages • Radiation exposure to the mediastinum • Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection - squamous cell carcinomas

questions.question:
Question 20: A patient with recurrent gastritis has been diagnosed with Helicobacter pylori infection. 
Which of the following is true in this patient?

options.a: Increased risk of adenocarcinoma of esophagus
options.b: Decreased risk of adenocarcinoma of esophagus
options.c: Increased risk of squamous cell carcinoma of esophagus
options.d: Decreased risk of squamous cell carcinoma of esophagus

questions.explanation:
Helicobacter pylori infection is associated with decreased risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma. Long-standing H. pylori gastritis (chronic inflammation) causes multifocal gastric mucosal 
atrophy, which in turn leads to reduced parietal cell mass, acid secretion. This leads to reduced 
incidence of Barrett's esophagus and decreased risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma. H. pylori infection, however, increases the risk of gastric adenocarcinoma.
